revisions.rev:
{{Infobox artist discography | Artist = The Corrs | Image = TheCorrs-group.jpg | Image size = 240px | Caption = The Corrs bid a concert audience farewell in 2005. (LâR: Sharon, Caroline, Andrea and Jim.) | Studio = 5 | Live = 3 | Compilation = 3 | Video = 6 | Video link = Video albums | Music videos = 22 | Singles = 25 }} [[The Corrs]] are an [[Republic of Ireland|Irish]] [[folk rock]]/[[pop music|pop]] band consisting of [[siblings]] [[Andrea Corr|Andrea]] ([[lead vocals]] and [[tin whistle]]), [[Sharon Corr|Sharon]] ([[violin]]), [[Caroline Corr|Caroline]] ([[drumkit|drums]] and [[bodhrÃ¡n]]) and [[Jim Corr]] ([[guitar]] and [[piano]]). Formed in their hometown of [[Dundalk]], [[Republic of Ireland]], in 1990, the band's discography includes five [[studio albums]] (all of which peaked at number one in the [[Irish Albums Chart]]), three [[live albums]] and three [[compilation album]]s, as well as six [[music video|video albums]] and twenty-five [[single (music)|singles]]. This list does not include material recorded by The Corrs as solo artists. Their debut album, ''[[Forgiven, Not Forgotten]]'', was produced by [[David Foster]] and released in 1995 by [[Atlantic Records]] in conjunction with [[143 Records]]. Preceded by debut single "[[Runaway (The Corrs song)|Runaway]]", the album was an immediate success in both their [[Ireland|home territory]] and [[Australia]], eventually being certified 13-times-platinum{{cite web|url=http://www.planet-corr.com/music/album-forgivennotforgotten.php |title=The Corrs - Forgiven, Not Forgotten |work=Planet Corr}}{{Dead link|date=October 2011}} and 9-times-platinum{{cite web | title = ''Forgiven, Not Forgotten'' & ''Unplugged'' Australian certificates | url = http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-2000.htm | publisher = [[Australian Recording Industry Association|ARIA]] |accessdate=23 December 2009 }} in those regions, respectively. Commercial success elsewhere was initially modest, however. Their 1997 follow-up, ''[[Talk on Corners|Talk On Corners]]'', was primarily produced by [[Glen Ballard]] and once again found The Corrs receiving little attention outside Ireland and Australia. Meanwhile, the group had contributed a cover of [[Fleetwood Mac]]'s "[[Dreams (Fleetwood Mac song)|Dreams]]" to ''Legacy: A Tribute to Fleetwood Mac's [[Rumours]]''. On 17 March 1998, they performed the song at London's [[Royal Albert Hall]] alongside Fleetwood Mac drummer [[Mick Fleetwood]] as part of the [[BBC]]'s televised coverage of [[Saint Patrick's Day|St. Patrick's Day]]. This event did much to raise the band's profile. Following this, ''[[Talk on Corners#Talk on Corners: Special Edition|Talk On Corners]]'' was re-released to include their cover of "[[Dreams (Fleetwood Mac song)#The Corrs version|Dreams]]," along with new single versions of "[[What Can I Do? (The Corrs song)|What Can I Do?]]", "[[So Young (The Corrs song)|So Young]]" and "[[Runaway (The Corrs song)|Runaway]]." Certified 9-times-platinum in the UK for sales of over 2.95 million copies, the album was the highest-selling release of 1998 and ninth highest-selling of 1999.{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/assets/files/Yearly%20best%20sellers%20-%20albums.pdf|title=Yearly Best Sellers - Albums|work=BPI.co.uk|accessdate=18 February 2010|format=PDF}} It remains the nineteenth best-selling album of all time in British chart history.{{cite web|url=http://www.bpi.co.uk/assets/files/top%2040%20albums.pdf|title=Top 40 Best Selling Albums 28 July 1956 â 14 June 2009|work=BPI.co.uk|accessdate=18 February 2010|format=PDF}} The album was certified 20Ã platinum in Ireland for shipments of over 300,000 units and remains the second-highest-selling album of all time in the region, after [[David Gray (musician)|David Gray]]'s ''[[White Ladder]]''. Their first live album, ''[[The Corrs Unplugged]]'', was released in 1999 and was followed ten months later by ''[[In Blue]]''. Dedicated to the memory of their mother Jean, who died during production of the album,{{cite web|url=http://www.independent.ie/national-news/stars-of-music-world-gather-to-mourn-with-the-corr-family-521563.html|title=Stars of music world gather to mourn with the Corr family|publisher=Independent Newspaper|date= 28 November 2000|accessdate=1 November 2007}} it went straight to number one in Ireland with the third highest opening week sales in the history of the chart.{{cite web|url=http://www.argus.ie/entertainment/corrs-tops-in-eight-countries-972160.html|title=Corrs, tops in eight countries|publisher=Independent Newspaper|date= 4 August 2000 |accessdate=1 November 2007}} Lead single "[[Breathless (The Corrs song)|Breathless]]" gave them their first and only UK number one,{{cite web|url=http://www.everyhit.com/ |title=UK Top 40 Hit Database |publisher=everyHit.com}} while the album also attained platinum status in the [[United States]] for shipments of over one million units.{{cite web|url=http://www.mfyi.com/c/corrsawards.html |title=The Corrs Awards |work=Mfyi.com |accessdate=26 October 2011}} The set has reportedly sold over 6.5 million copies worldwide.{{Citation needed|date=October 2011}} 2004 saw the release of ''[[Borrowed Heaven]]''. Dedicated to their parents,{{cite web|url=http://www.cluas.com/music/albums/corrs-home.htm|title=The Corrs's album 'Home'|author=Maher, Gareth|publisher=CLUAS.com|accessdate=2 November 2007}} the album was a return to their [[Celts|Celtic]] roots after the more pop-oriented ''In Blue''. It peaked at number one in Ireland and achieved platinum status both there and in Australia,[http://www.aria.com.au/pages/aria-charts-accreditations-albums-2004.htm "ARIA Charts - Accreditations - 2004 Albums"]. [[Australian Recording Industry Association]]. Retrieved 30 May 2010. with gold status also being attained in [[France]],[http://www.disqueenfrance.com/fr/monopage.xml?id=259165&year=2004&type=8 "Disque En France"]. [[Syndicat National de l'Ãdition Phonographique]]. Retrieved 30 May 2010. [[Germany]]{{cite certification|region=Germany|title=Borrowed%20Heaven|accessdate=30 May 2010}} and [[New Zealand]],[http://www.rianz.org.nz/rianz/chart.asp "RIANZ: Chart #1411 - Monday 7 June 2004 / Top 40 Albums Chart"]. [[RIANZ]]. Retrieved 30 May 2010. among others. ''[[Home (The Corrs album)|Home]]'', which featured traditional Irish music taken from their late mother's songbook,{{cite web|url=http://www.musicremedy.com/t/The_Corrs/album/Home-2329.html|title=The Corrs 'Home' album|publisher=MusicRemedy.com|accessdate=2 November 2007}} was released the following year, serving as a commemoration to their 15-year career.{{cite web|url=http://www.popmatters.com/pm/music/reviews/the_corrs_home/|title=The Corrs: Home|publisher=Popmatters.com|author=Weisinger, Mark|date=7 March 2006|accessdate=2 November 2007}} 2006's ''[[Dreams: The Ultimate Corrs Collection]]'' was released following the announcement that the band would go on indefinite hiatus for the foreseeable future, citing personal reasons. In 2006, both Sharon and Caroline gave birth to children, and Jim became a father for the first time. Since 2005, Andrea has had starring roles in three feature films, acted in the play ''[[Dancing at Lughnasa]]'' and has released two solo albums, ''[[Ten Feet High]]'' in 2007 and ''[[Lifelines (Andrea Corr album)|Lifelines]]'' in 2011. Sharon released her first solo album, ''[[Dream of You (Sharon Corr album)|Dream of You]]'' in 2010. The Corrs have sold more than 40 million albums worldwide.{{cite web|url=http://www.sharoncorr.com/biography/ |title=Biography |publisher=Sharon Corr |accessdate=26 October 2011}} ==Studio albums== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" border="1" |+ List of albums, with selected chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:8em;"| Title ! scope="col" rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Album details ! scope="col" colspan="13"| Peak chart positions ! scope="col" rowspan="2"| [[List of music recording certifications|Certifications]] |- ! scope="col" style="width:3em;font-size:90%;"|[[Irish Albums Chart|IRL]]
